title: Former Los Angeles Dodgers Owner Sells Palm Beach Mansion for Almost $100M
text:
Billionaire businessman and former owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team Frank McCourt has sold his Palm Beach, Florida, mansion for $99.13 million, according to property records.



The off-market deal, which fell just short of hitting the nine-figure threshold, hit records on Friday.



More: Bette Midler Lists Manhattan Penthouse for $50 Million

Mr. McCourt, 66, who now owns the French soccer club Olympique de Marseille, paid $77.06 million for the beachfront spread in 2017, according to property records. He used a trust for his purchase.



The buyer of the mansion—which has eight bedrooms and 10 bathrooms, according to the limited information available online—shielded their identity using a limited liability company.



The man behind the LLC is reportedly big property spender Ken Griffin, according to the Palm Beach Daily News, who first reported the sale. Mansion Global could not independently confirm he is the buyer.



The hedge fund billionaire, who founded Chicago-based Citadel, has become well known for his extravagant, and often record-breaking, real estate acquisitions.



They include a $239.9 million apartment in Manhattan, marking a record for the highest-priced home ever sold in the U.S.; a £95 million (US$117.29 million) London townhouse overlooking St James’s Park; and a $58 million home in Chicago at the top of a new condo development.

Property records link Mr. Griffin to several of the home’s surrounding parcels, suggesting that the billionaire has strong ties to the enclave.



A press representative for Mr. Griffin, 50, declined to comment.



The billionaire pedigree for the compound extends back to the late 1990s.



Mr. McCourt, who could not be reached for comment, bought the mansion from a holding company tied to Venezuelan banker and polo player Victor Vargas, who in turn had purchased the home from the late Florida-based billionaire and entrepreneur George Lindemann, Mansion Global previously reported.
